introduction.title: The Central Dogma of Molecular Biology
introduction.content: The Central Dogma describes the flow of genetic information in living organisms. This fundamental principle explains how genetic instructions stored in DNA are converted into functional proteins that perform cellular work.
keyPoints: DNA contains the genetic blueprint of life
Information flows from DNA to RNA to Proteins
This process is universal across all life forms
Each step is highly regulated and precise

transcription.title: DNA Transcription: Creating the Message
transcription.content: Transcription is the first step where genetic information is copied from DNA into messenger RNA (mRNA). This process occurs in the nucleus and is carried out by RNA polymerase enzymes.
keyPoints: RNA polymerase reads the DNA template strand (3' to 5')
mRNA is synthesized in the 5' to 3' direction
Thymine (T) in DNA is replaced by Uracil (U) in RNA
The process includes initiation, elongation, and termination

vocabulary.RNA Polymerase: The enzyme that synthesizes RNA from a DNA template
vocabulary.Template Strand: The DNA strand used as a template for RNA synthesis
vocabulary.Promoter: DNA sequence where RNA polymerase binds to start transcription

translation.title: RNA Translation: Building Proteins
translation.content: Translation is the process where mRNA is decoded by ribosomes to produce proteins. Transfer RNA (tRNA) molecules deliver specific amino acids based on the genetic code.
keyPoints: Ribosomes are the protein synthesis machinery
The genetic code is read in triplets called codons
Each codon specifies one amino acid
Start codon (AUG) begins translation, stop codons end it

vocabulary.Ribosome: Cellular structure where proteins are synthesized
vocabulary.Codon: Three-nucleotide sequence that codes for an amino acid
vocabulary.tRNA: Transfer RNA that delivers amino acids to the ribosome

questions.question: What enzyme is responsible for transcribing DNA into mRNA?
questions.explanation: RNA polymerase is the enzyme that reads DNA and synthesizes complementary mRNA during transcription.

questions.question: In which direction does RNA polymerase read the DNA template strand?
questions.explanation: RNA polymerase reads the DNA template strand in the 3' to 5' direction, synthesizing mRNA in the 5' to 3' direction.

questions.question: What nucleotide in mRNA replaces thymine from DNA?
questions.explanation: Uracil (U) replaces thymine (T) in RNA. So DNA's A-T base pairs become A-U base pairs in mRNA.

questions.question: How many nucleotides make up one codon?
questions.explanation: A codon consists of three nucleotides. This triplet code allows for 64 possible combinations (4¬≥) to specify 20 amino acids plus start/stop signals.

questions.question: What is the start codon for protein synthesis?
questions.explanation: AUG is the start codon that initiates protein synthesis and codes for methionine, the first amino acid in most proteins.

questions.question: Where does translation occur in the cell?
questions.explanation: Translation occurs at ribosomes, which can be found free in the cytoplasm or attached to the endoplasmic reticulum.

tips.title: Memory Tip: Base Pairing
tips.content: Remember DNA base pairing with 'ATGC': Adenine with Thymine, Guanine with Cytosine. In RNA, Thymine becomes Uracil!

tips.title: Directional Flow
tips.content: Think of the Central Dogma as a one-way street: DNA ‚Üí RNA ‚Üí Protein. Information flows in this direction!

tips.title: Codon Triplets
tips.content: Codons work in groups of 3 because 3 bases provide 64 combinations (4¬≥), enough for 20 amino acids plus start/stop signals.

tips.title: RNA Polymerase Direction
tips.content: RNA polymerase 'unzips' DNA and reads 3'‚Üí5' to write mRNA 5'‚Üí3'. Think of it as reading backwards to write forwards!

glossary.Central Dogma: The principle that genetic information flows from DNA to RNA to proteins
glossary.Transcription: The process of copying genetic information from DNA to mRNA
glossary.Translation: The process of converting mRNA into proteins using ribosomes
glossary.DNA: Deoxyribonucleic acid - the molecule that stores genetic information
glossary.RNA: Ribonucleic acid - various types involved in protein synthesis
glossary.mRNA: Messenger RNA - carries genetic information from DNA to ribosomes
glossary.tRNA: Transfer RNA - delivers amino acids to ribosomes during translation
glossary.Ribosome: Cellular structure where proteins are synthesized
glossary.Codon: Three-nucleotide sequence that specifies an amino acid
glossary.RNA Polymerase: Enzyme that synthesizes RNA from DNA template
glossary.Stop Codon: UAA, UAG, or UGA - terminates protein synthesis
glossary.Genetic Code: The set of rules by which information in DNA/RNA is translated into proteins

keyframes.description: RNA polymerase recognizes and binds to the promoter region
DNA double helix unwinds to expose the template strand
RNA polymerase begins moving along DNA, synthesizing mRNA
mRNA chain grows as RNA polymerase progresses
Transcription terminates when RNA polymerase reaches stop signal
Small and large ribosomal subunits assemble on mRNA
tRNA molecules deliver amino acids matching codons
Amino acids join together forming peptide bonds
Ribosome moves to next codon, continuing synthesis
Stop codon reached, protein synthesis complete
